author: Stephen Schaefer
title: Malala’s story
text:
A remarkable true story that seemed destined for the big screen, “He Named Me Malala” (opening Friday) finds Oscar-winning documentarian Davis Guggenheim (2006’s “An Inconvenient Truth”) going beyond the headlines in his profile of Pakistani teenager Malala Yousafzai.
“I always want my films to go deeper than just skim the surface,” Guggenheim, 51, said. “What had been most reported about her was that she was the 15-year-old girl shot on her school bus and, at 17, won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2014.
“I found there was something so much richer than what we think we know: This is a father-daughter story about their personal relationship and the choices they make.”
Her father Ziauddin co-authored her global best-seller, “I Am Malala,” and has said, “We’re one soul in two bodies.”
A teacher, he named her after a 19th century Afghani woman warrior who died in battle.
“That blew my mind,” Guggenheim said. “Her father names her after a character who speaks out and is killed for speaking out. So the movie asks, ‘Is her life predestined?’
“She says, ‘No, he named me Malala. But he didn’t make me Malala. This is my life and I’m going to live it.’ ”
There’s a startling moment when Guggenheim questions Malala about her suffering and she will not answer.
“She does not dwell on those things,” the filmmaker said. “I think, partly it is she knows there are millions of other girls who are suffering right now.”
Continued the Los Angeles resident, “I come from a part of the country where if you don’t get your cold-pressed coffee served correctly, people complain all day.
“Malala knows what it’s like to be a refugee, to have her school closed, her father threatened, her friends killed. People who have been like that — you see that with American soldiers who have been in conflict — they don’t like to talk about their suffering. There’s a stoicism and a modesty about it.
“But I also think she’s a deeply felt individual. It’s not as if she’s in denial about it; I just think she’s not willing to dwell on suffering.”
Guggenheim says the father and daughter changed his life.
“After being with them, I came home and asked myself, ‘Am I as righteous as this man?’ He inspired me to be a better father.”
